definition: Qin Shihuang (259-210 BC), the first emperor
Qin dynasty (221-207 BC), founded by the first emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2], the first dynasty to rule the whole of China
Han Dynasty (206 BC-220 AD)
Western Han Dynasty (206 BC-8 AD), also called 前漢|前汉[Qian2 Han4], Former Han Dynasty
the state of Qin, one of the seven states of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Qin Ershi (229-207 BC), second Qin emperor
Shang Yang's political reform of Qin state 秦國|秦国 of 356 BC and 350 BC, that put it on the road to world domination
Chen Sheng Wu Guang Uprising (209 BC), near the end of the Qin dynasty
pinyin: Chen2 Sheng4 Wu2 Guang3 Qi3 yi4

definition: posthumous name of the first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦 (256 or 247-195 BC), reigned 202-195 BC
Zhou Dynasty/Western Zhou 西周 (1046-771 BC) and Eastern Zhou 東周|东周 (770-221 BC)
the Spring and Autumn (770-476 BC) and Warring States (475-221 BC) periods
to burn the Confucian classics and bury alive the Confucian scholars (acts supposedly committed by the first emperor 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2])
Sui dynasty (581-617)

Shang Yang (c. 390-338 BC), legalist philosopher and statesman of the state of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], whose reforms paved the way for the eventual unification of the Chinese empire by the Qin dynasty 秦朝|秦朝[Qin2 chao2]
Shang Dynasty (c. 1600-1046 BC)
